unnormalised: ## Decoding Rental Yields: Is Your Mumbai Investment Paying Off?
normalised: ## Decoding Rental Yields: Is Your Mumbai Investment Paying Off?

unnormalised: Hey folks! Let's talk rental yields. You bought that lovely 2BHK in Bandra West, dreaming of passive income and early retirement, right? But are you actually making money, or is your investment just sitting pretty, eating into your bank balance? That’s where rental yield comes in.
normalised: Hey folks! Let's talk rental yields. You bought that lovely two B H K in Bandra West, dreaming of passive income and early retirement, right? But are you actually making money, or is your investment just sitting pretty, eating into your bank balance? That’s where rental yield comes in.

unnormalised: Basically, rental yield is the percentage return you get on your investment property each year from rent. It helps you understand if your property is a good investment. Think of it like this: if you bought a property for Rs. 1 Crore and you're getting Rs. 25,000 rent per month (Rs. 3,00,000 annually), your gross rental yield is 3%. Not exactly blowing anyone's mind, is it?
normalised: Basically, rental yield is the percentage return you get on your investment property each year from rent. It helps you understand if your property is a good investment. Think of it like this: if you bought a property for rupee one crore and you're getting rupee twenty five thousand rent per month (rupee three hundred thousand annually), your gross rental yield is three percent. Not exactly blowing anyone's mind, is it?

normalised: Now, calculating rental yield isn't rocket science (though Doctor Sharma down the street might disagree!). It's pretty straightforward:

unnormalised: **(Annual Rental Income / Property Value) x 100 = Rental Yield %**
normalised: **(Annual Rental Income divided by Property Value) multiplied by one hundred equals Rental Yield percent**

unnormalised: But hold on! Don't just look at the *gross* rental yield. Factor in all those hidden expenses! Think property taxes (BMC, anyone?), maintenance charges (that cracked tile in the bathroom won't fix itself!), and even those pesky society fees. That’s your *net* rental yield. It's often a more realistic picture.
normalised: But hold on! Don't just look at the *gross* rental yield. Factor in all those hidden expenses! Think property taxes (B M C, anyone?), maintenance charges (that cracked tile in the bathroom won't fix itself!), and even those pesky society fees. That’s your *net* rental yield. unnormalised: So, if your maintenance and taxes come out to Rs. 50,000 a year, your *net* rental income is actually Rs. 2,50,000. That makes your net rental yield only 2.5%. A bit of a difference, eh?
normalised: So, if your maintenance and taxes come out to rupee fifty thousand a year, your *net* rental income is actually rupee two hundred and fifty thousand. That makes your net rental yield only two point five percent. A bit of a difference, eh?

unnormalised: Different cities and even different localities within a city will have varying rental yields. A smaller flat (say, 500 sq ft) near a college like IIT Bombay might fetch a higher yield than a sprawling 3BHK 20 km outside the city center. Location matters!
